mechanism_of_action: Warfarin inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and anticoagulant proteins C and S. It interferes with the cyclic interconversion of vitamin K and vitamin K epoxide, reducing the amount of active vitamin K available for the carboxylation of clotting factors.
indications: Prophylaxis and treatment of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
Prophylaxis and treatment of thromboembolic complications associated with atrial fibrillation
Prophylaxis and treatment of thromboembolic complications associated with cardiac valve replacement
Reduction of risk of death, recurrent MI, and thromboembolic events such as stroke after MI
contraindications: Active bleeding or bleeding tendency (hemophilia, recent surgery, active GI ulceration)
Patient non-compliance or inability to cooperate
Recent or contemplated CNS surgery or eye surgery
Lumbar puncture and other diagnostic or therapeutic procedures with potential for uncontrollable bleeding

black_box: BLEEDING RISK: Warfarin can cause major or fatal bleeding. Bleeding is more likely during the starting period and with higher doses. Risk factors include high intensity anticoagulation (INR > 4), age ≥ 65, history of GI bleeding, hypertension, cerebrovascular disease, serious heart disease, anemia, malignancy, trauma, renal insufficiency, drug-drug interactions, long duration of therapy, and poor anticoagulant control.
Regular monitoring of INR is essential. Dose adjustments must be individualized based on INR response.

PREGNANCY: Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy. It crosses the placenta and can cause fatal hemorrhage to the fetus and congenital malformations. Women of childbearing potential must use effective contraception.
serious: Calciphylaxis (calcium uremic arteriolopathy) - rare but serious
Skin necrosis (usually appears between days 3-8 of therapy)
precautions: Genetic factors affect dosing (CYP2C9 and VKORC1 polymorphisms)
Increased bleeding risk with concurrent use of antiplatelet agents or NSAIDs
Vitamin K-rich foods can decrease efficacy

dosing.adult_dose: Initial: 2-5 mg once daily (consider 2-3 mg in elderly or patients at high bleeding risk). Adjust based on INR. Typical maintenance: 2-10 mg once daily.
dosing.pediatric_dose: Individualized based on INR. Initial: 0.1-0.2 mg/kg/day (max 10 mg). Infants may require higher doses.
dosing.geriatric_adjustments: Lower starting doses recommended (2-3 mg daily). Elderly patients may be more sensitive to warfarin and have increased bleeding risk. More frequent INR monitoring advised.
dosing.renal_adjustment: No specific dose adjustment required, but monitor INR more frequently. Increased bleeding risk with renal impairment.
dosing.hepatic_adjustment: Contraindicated in severe hepatic disease. Use with caution in mild-moderate disease with more frequent INR monitoring.

interactions.management: Avoid concurrent use if possible. If necessary, use lowest effective doses and monitor closely for bleeding.

interactions.effect: Increased bleeding risk, especially GI bleeding
interactions.management: Avoid if possible. Consider acetaminophen for pain. If NSAID necessary, use lowest dose for shortest duration and monitor INR.
Increase INR monitoring frequency. May need temporary warfarin dose reduction.
Reduce warfarin dose by 30-50% when starting amiodarone. Monitor INR closely.
May need to increase warfarin dose. Monitor INR closely when starting or stopping rifampin.
Consider dose reduction. Monitor INR closely.
Avoid vitamin K supplements. Maintain consistent dietary vitamin K intake.
Limit alcohol intake. Chronic heavy use may decrease INR.

common: Bleeding (most common - ranges from minor to major)
adverse_effects.frequency: Bleeding complications occur in 15-20% of patients per year, with major bleeding in 1-3% per year

monitoring_frequency.initiation: INR daily or every other day until stable
monitoring_frequency.stable_therapy: INR every 4 weeks (some patients may need more frequent monitoring)
monitoring_frequency.after_dose_change: INR within 3-7 days, then weekly until stable

patient_considerations.breastfeeding_note: Low levels in breast milk. Appears safe but monitor infant for bruising/bleeding.
age_related: Elderly (≥65 years): Increased sensitivity, higher bleeding risk, lower starting doses recommended
Pediatric: Limited data, requires individualized dosing and close monitoring

pharmacogenetics.cyp2c9: Polymorphisms (*2 and *3 alleles) result in reduced enzyme activity and increased bleeding risk. May require lower doses.
pharmacogenetics.vkorc1: Genetic variants affect warfarin sensitivity. Lower doses may be needed in some patients.
pharmacogenetics.testing: Pharmacogenetic testing may guide initial dosing but is not routinely required.

reversal_strategies.minor_bleeding_inr_elevated: Hold warfarin, give oral vitamin K 2.5-5 mg
reversal_strategies.major_bleeding: Hold warfarin, give IV vitamin K 10 mg slow infusion PLUS 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) or fresh frozen plasma if PCC unavailable
reversal_strategies.emergent_surgery: 4-factor PCC plus vitamin K 5-10 mg IV

inr_elevated_no_bleeding.inr_4.5_to_10: Hold 1-2 doses, monitor INR, resume at lower dose when therapeutic
inr_elevated_no_bleeding.inr_greater_than_10: Hold warfarin, give oral vitamin K 2.5-5 mg

dietary_considerations.counseling: Maintain consistent vitamin K intake. Don't avoid these foods, but keep intake consistent from week to week.
dietary_considerations.cranberry_juice: May increase INR. Limit or avoid.
